comments: G.f. for column m: see column sequences: A000012, A000071, A056589-91, for m=0..4.The row polynomials p(n,x) := sum(a(n,m)*x^m) occur as numerators of the g.f. for the (n+1)-th power of Fibonacci numbers A000045. The corresponding denominator polynomials are the row polynomials q(n+2,x)= sum(A055870(n+2,m)*x^m,m=0..n+2) (signed Fibonomial triangle).The row polynomials p(n,x) and the companion denominator polynomials q(n,x) can be deduced from Riordan's recursion result.The explicit formula is found from the recursion relation for powers of Fibonacci numbers (see Knuth's exercise with solution). - _Roger L. Bagula_, Apr 03 2010
references: A. Brousseau, A sequence of power formulas, Fib. Quart., 6 (1968), 81-83.
D. E. Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming. Addison-Wesley, Reading, MA, 1969, Vol. 1, p. 84, (exercise 1.2.8. Nr. 30) and p. 492 (solution).
J. Riordan, Generating functions for powers of Fibonacci numbers, Duke. Math. J. 29 (1962) 5-12.
links: S. Falcon, On The Generating Functions of the Powers of the K-Fibonacci Numbers, Scholars Journal of Engineering and Technology (SJET), 2014; 2 (4C):669-675.
formula: a(n, m)=0 if n<m; a(n, 0)=1; a(n, m)= F(m+1)^(n+1) + sum(sfibonomial(n+2, j)*(F(m+1-j)^(n+1)), j=1..m) m=1..n, with F(n)=A000045(n) (Fibonacci) and sfibonomial(n, m) := A055870(n, m).From _Roger L. Bagula_, Apr 03 2010: (Start)p(x,n)=Sum[(((1 + Sqrt[5])^k - (1 - Sqrt[5])^k)/(2^k* Sqrt[5]))^n*x^k, {k, 0, Infinity}];t(n,m)=Numerator_coefficients(p(x,n)/x)/2^(1 + Floor[n/2]);out_n,m]=t(n,m)/t(n,1) (End)
maple: A056588 := proc(n,k)    if k = 0 then        1;    elif k >n then        0;    else        combinat[fibonacci](k+1)^(n+1)+add( A055870(n+2, j)*(combinat[fibonacci](k+1-j)^(n+1)), j=1..k) ;    end if;end proc: # _R. J. Mathar_, Jun 14 2015
mathematica: Contribution from _Roger L. Bagula_, Apr 03 2010: (Start)p[x_, n_] = Sum[(((1 + Sqrt[5])^k - (1 - Sqrt[5])^k)/(2^k*Sqrt[5]))^n*x^k, {k, 0, Infinity}];a = Table[CoefficientList[FullSimplify[Numerator[p[ x, n]]/x], x]/2^(1 + Floor[n/2]), {n, 1, 10}];Table[a[[n]]/a[[n]][[1]], {n, 1, 10}];Flatten[%] (End)
author: _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jul 10 2000
